title: If a pet need a blood transfusion where does the blood come from? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am not an expert, but in a story a vet needed a small amount of blood for a dog, I think. Cat is possible. It was the equivalent of a human needing 1 bag, they might be okay without it as the bleeding had been stopped, but they would have been weakened so things were more likely to go . One of the vet’s pets both was the equivalent of O- for the species and was not upset by donating. From what I have read, that checks out. Vets know of cats, dogs, and horses etc, who can either donate on a schedule for the vet to store or whose humans are willing to bring them down when another animal of the same species is going to have surgery. Animals who know they will get enough treats, cuddles, whatever is their favorite currency to make the poke just another strange Human thing that the animal doesn’t need to get upset with anymore. Not as much help when the other animal is hemorrhaging but a single donation from a human can be enough to make the difference to a moderately injured person with a decent team working to clamp the torn arteries.

Pets often require blood transfusions due to illness or injury. Unfortunately there aren’t too many blood banks for animal blood. Vets normally depend on donor blood in such instances. Dogs donate to dogs, cats to cats, etc.
